meanings.def: an activity that you do to have fun, often one that has rules and that you can win or lose; the equipment for a game
examples: The kids were playing a game with their balloons.
The children invented a new game.
a video/computer game
I play online games with my friends.
a game of chance/skill
Buy your games and software from us.
Her main interests are music and gardening.
His hobbies include swimming and cooking.
a game of cops and robbers
He was playing games with the dog.
Eating out is the national pastime in France.
Children love learning new games.
Chess is a game of skill.
The company is developing games to play on mobile phones.
It's hard to find indoor games for children.
This is a good game for getting people to mix.
children's party games like Musical Chairs
I have been an avid roleplaying game fan for more than 20 years.
competitive games in which there is always a winner and a loser
Millions of people buy racing games every year.

meanings.def: a sport with rules in which people or teams compete against each other
examples: ball games, such as football or tennis
How I hated team games at school!
the game of something the game of golf/cricket/basketball
Broadcasters have injected vast amounts of money into the game of football.

meanings.def: an occasion of playing a game
examples: to win/lose a game
They lost their first home game of the season.
a baseball/basketball game
(especially North American English) a football game
(North American English) We're going to the ball game (= baseball game).
Are you coming to watch the game?
a game of something to play a game of chess
Let's have a game of table tennis.
game against somebody Saturday’s League game against Swansea
game with somebody today's game with Manchester United
They're in training for the big game.
The defence are coming under pressure for the first time in this game.
their first League game of the season
United are playing a home game this week.
The team fought back to level the game.
The early stages of the game were dominated by the home team.
Last night he played the final game of his career.
It's going to be a close game.
He's hoping to be fit before next week's game with Liverpool.
Trescothick had a good game and was man of the match.
We won the first game and drew the second.
He pitched a perfect game at Atlanta.

meanings.def: the way in which somebody plays a game
examples: Maguire raised his game to collect the £40 000 first prize.
Stretching exercises can help you avoid injury and improve your game.

meanings.def: a large organized sports event
examples: She's hoping to participate in the next Olympic Games.
To stage the Games (= the Olympic Games or a similar event) is an honour.

meanings.def: sport as a lesson or an activity at school
examples: I always hated games at school.

meanings.def: a section of some games, such as tennis, which forms a unit in scoring
examples: two games all (= both players have won two games)
Zverev won the opening game of the third set.

meanings.def: a type of activity or business
examples: How long have you been in this game?
the game of politics
I'm new to this game myself.
Getting dirty was all part of the game to the kids.
Lufthansa entered the game with a 25% stake in the company.
Predicting the outcome of the election is a game of chance.

meanings.def: a secret and clever plan; a trick
examples: So that's his game (= now I know what he has been planning).
He was unwittingly caught up in a dangerous game of lies and betrayals.
I realized that he had been playing a stupid game with me.
I'll soon put an end to her silly little games.

meanings.def: wild animals or birds that people hunt for sport or food
at an advantage/disadvantage because you have done more/less preparation or know more/less than other people, especially those you are competing against
examples: We'll be able to extract insights out of the data that will enable us to stay ahead of the game.
Politicians are behind the game in understanding how fast the world is changing.

meanings.def: to defeat or do better than somebody in an activity which they have chosen or in which they think they are strong
to not be considered to be serious
examples: For her the whole project was just a game.

meanings.def: to be working as a prostitute
to no longer have a chance of winning a game or succeeding in an activity that you are taking part in
to still/once again have a good chance of winning a game or succeeding in an activity that you are taking part in
examples: The team was still in the game, just one goal down.
(figurative) He’s been fighting to get the struggling company back in the game.

meanings.def: activities that are not serious and that other people may think are bad
examples: Teaching isn't all fun and games, you know.

meanings.def: said to somebody who has done something wrong, when they are caught and the crime or trick has been discovered
examples: Maggie knew that he had recognized her and the game was up.

meanings.def: used after something has happened that makes it clear that a contest is not yet decided and anyone could still win
examples: We were losing 2–0 with ten minutes to go, and then we scored. It was game on!

meanings.def: used to say that it is no longer possible for somebody/something to succeed, survive or continue
examples: Given her recent slump in form, it might be game over already this season.
This technology could mean game over for gasoline-powered vehicles.
The slightest mistake and it's game over for him.

meanings.def: to tell a secret, especially by accident; to show something that should be kept hidden
examples: Don't let him talk to anybody or he'll give the game away.

meanings.def: an activity that is unlikely to be successful or make a profit
the most important aspect of an activity; the most important quality needed for an activity
examples: Hard work is the name of the game if you want to succeed in business.

meanings.def: the advantages to be gained from doing something are not great enough, considering the effort or cost involved
examples: If the price goes up again, he may decide that the game’s not worth the candle.

meanings.def: a way of considering an activity, etc. that considers only the number of people doing something, things achieved, etc., not with who or what they are
examples: MPs were playing the numbers game as the crucial vote drew closer.

meanings.def: performing badly/well, especially when compared with how well you usually perform
examples: He was off his game and missed two early penalties.

meanings.def: the most important thing of a particular type, or the only thing that is available
to play a cruel game with somebody in your power by changing your behaviour very often, so that they become nervous and do not know what to expect
examples: He thought the police were playing some elaborate game of cat and mouse and waiting to trap him.
Young car thieves enjoy playing cat and mouse with the police.

meanings.def: to do something that helps somebody else’s plans, especially by accident, when you did not intend to help them
to behave in a fair and honest way
examples: You can’t do that—it’s not playing the game!

meanings.def: not to treat a situation seriously, especially in order to cheat somebody
examples: Don't play silly games with me; I know you did it.

meanings.def: the standards of behaviour that most people accept or that actually operate in a particular area of life or business
to talk in a way that sounds convincing, but may not be sincere
examples: The senior managers talk a good game about customer relations, but really they don't care about the customer.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody who has played a trick on you that you can do the same thing to them
to improve the level at which you can compete, especially in a sport
examples: She's really upped her game since she joined the tennis club.
With these two snazzy new restaurants opening up, the other eating places in the area are going to have to up their game.

meanings.def: used to ask why somebody is behaving as they are

meanings.def: to risk money playing a game of chance
to play video games
to use something in a way that is unfair but legal, in order to get what you want
examples: Some companies only received a government grant because they gamed the system.
The government finance programme is being gamed by some high-profile banks.

meanings.def: to treat somebody who trusts you in an unfair way in order to get what you want
examples: He gamed his publishers, his family and his friends in order to make a success of his autobiography.

meanings.def: ready and willing to do something new, difficult or dangerous
examples: She's game for anything.
We need a volunteer for this exercise. Who's game to try?
